awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Terrestrial Denitrification and Environmental Change
awd_abstract_narration:
Nitrogen is a vital plant nutrient, and its availability often limits tree growth. The microbial process of denitrification removes available nitrogen from ecosystems and produces a range of nitrogen gases, including nitrous oxide, a potent greenhouse gas. Earth system models often fail to capture the magnitude or global distribution of these nitrogen gas losses. Denitrification occurs under low-oxygen conditions, and measurements are complicated by both analytical challenges and tremendous spatial and temporal variation. This project will apply a suite of measurement approaches to test hypotheses about the way that several environmental factors regulate denitrification, and it will improve the representation of denitrification in an important earth system model. This research has important implications for policies regulating nitrogen as an air and water pollutant, and improvements to the earth system model support international science and policy programs for predicting future environmental change.

This project will advance understanding of the environmental regulation of denitrification in both field studies at the Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest in New Hampshire and as represented by the Community Land Model (CLM-CN). At Hubbard Brook, the project will test the role of several environmental factors hypothesized to regulate denitrification, including soil oxygen levels, soil depth, rainfall variability, soil warming, and soil acidification. The project will deploy measurement approaches that include soil core-based fluxes of nitrogen gases, continuous soil oxygen sensors, chamber-based gas fluxes, and nitrate stable isotopes. Together these measurements will provide a comprehensive assessment of denitrification and its environmental drivers, and will enable this project to improve representation of plant-microbe competition and carbon-nitrogen-oxygen biogeochemistry in the Community Land Model. The project will also train two graduate students and one postdoctoral associate, and it will offer hands-on biogeochemistry boot camps for diverse groups of graduate students on the advanced techniques used for measuring greenhouse gas emissions and related ecosystem processes.

por.por_cntn:
In this collaborative research study across multiple institutions, we tested hypotheses about the environmental regulation of terrestrial denitrification, which in turn is an important control over nitrogen availability for plant growth and decomposition in soils. 

The five regulators of denitrification that we investigated in this study were:
(1) low- to mid-levels of soil oxygen (5-10%), which enable coupling of nitrate production in aerobic conditions with its consumption by denitrification;
(2) production of dissolved organic carbon (DOC) and nitrate in aerobic surface soils that flush to deeper soils with lower-oxygen conditions that promote denitrification;
(3) increased precipitation amount and variability (drying/wetting cycles), which produce bursts of nitrification, DOC release, and soil respiration that reduces soil oxygen;
(4) soil warming, which enhances denitrification through increased nitrate supply and consumption of oxygen; and
(5) soil acidity, which affects microbial function and supplies of DOC and nitrate.

At Portland State University, we focused on items 3) and 5). For the investigation of the effects of precipitation amount and variability on soil denitrification, we conducted a parallel analysis of denitrification in the drying/wetting cycles experiment using a new core-based system analogous to that in one of our partners' research lab. Unfortunately, due to multiple, unresolved technical issues with the new instrument configuration, we were unable to directly compare our results. The results generated in the other lab therefore provided the main analytical results for the project. 

To investigate the role of soil acidity on denitrification, we also examined the 20-year dataset of soil nitrogen and carbon dynamics in paired watersheds following the experimental watershed calcium (Ca) treatment (1999) at Hubbard Brook Experimental Forest. Non-linear trends were found in elevated soil pH in the Ca-treated watershed, with stronger effects seen in surface soil horizons, with declines over time that converged toward reference conditions by 2018. Soil nitrogen cycling measurements were not consistent with the changes in soil pH, and temporal trends were different depending on the variable in question. Differences in temporal trends in nitrogen cycling variables were often more pronounced as a function of soil horizon than Ca treatment. However, interesting trends were seen in certain variables, with effects of Ca treatment diverging from long term trends in the reference area for some variables while converging toward reference conditions for others. Because pathways in soil nitrogen cycling did not show consistent trajectories over time in response to the calcium treatment, understanding how changes in soil pH and other environmental variables, along with competition for nitrogen between plants and soil microbes, differentially affect these various processes remains a challenge in forest ecosystem science.

In connection with the work completed by our collaborators on this project, this work has advanced our understanding of soil denitrification by
1) narrowing gaps between empirical data and Earth-system nitrogen cycle modeling approaches; 2) providing more empirical evidence of the finescale complexity of environmental controls over soil denitrification rates and products; and 3) exploring the complex temporal dynamics of soil
nitrogen cycling as a function of climate changes and experimental changes in soil acidity.
